{
  "article_text": [
    "information processing does not come for free .",
    "physical systems are needed to store , transmit and process information , and these come with physical resource costs , in time , space and energy .",
    "the heat generated by information processing is becoming one of the most significant of these costs .",
    "modern integrated circuits have power densities of the order @xmath0 with operating temperatures near to their upper limit @xcite .",
    "thermal management is already the main constraint on the performance of modern electronics and advances in technology will increasingly need to test the fundamental limits of energy consumption .    for classical information processing , landauer s principle",
    "@xcite relates the change in information from a computation to a minimum thermodynamic cost in the form of heat generated in the environment .",
    "the information content of a source of signals is measured by the shannon measure @xmath1 , where @xmath2 is the probability of signal @xmath3 occurring .",
    "landauer s principle states that the mean heat generated by an information processing device is given by @xmath4 where @xmath5 is the change in the shannon information .    the limit cost , which corresponds to the condition of thermodynamic reversibility @xcite , is defined purely in terms of the information processing operation itself : every physical system which performs the task must pay at least this cost @xcite .",
    "most importantly , it is a tight bound : while there are practical barriers to reaching the limit ( finite size and time effects , single shot costs , etc .",
    "@xcite ) there is no physical principle that prevents their effects becoming arbitrarily small , with experimental tests increasingly pushing at this boundary @xcite .",
    "this tight relationship between information theory and thermodynamics makes landauer s principle the basis of our understanding of the thermodynamic cost of information processing .",
    "however , both the theoretical studies and experimental tests of the landauer limit have almost exclusively considered classical information processing .",
    "quantum computing radically alters the nature of information , leading to many attempts to extend landauer s principle to quantum theory @xcite .    quantum information processing involves a quantum system @xmath6 with states @xmath7 as signal states , undergoing a quantum operation @xmath8 , defined by its effect upon the signal states @xmath9 .",
    "given that the input @xmath7 appears with probability @xmath2 , the average input is @xmath10 , and the average output is @xmath11 .",
    "the natural quantum generalisation of shannon information to quantum theory is the schumacher information measure @xmath12 $ ] @xcite , which agrees with the shannon information when the signal states are orthogonal .",
    "this suggests that equation  ( [ clp ] ) should be replaced by @xmath13 .",
    "\\label{bound}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] while it is well known that equation  ( [ bound ] ) must hold , and that reaching the equality is required for thermodynamic reversibility @xcite , we show that it fails as a tight bound for quantum information processing .",
    "there is an unavoidable excess heat generation in quantum computation that is not present in the classical case .      for any given quantum operation @xmath8",
    "there is non negative quantity @xmath14 , defined independently of how the quantum operation is physically implemented , such that the heat generated by the operation is bounded by : @xmath15 + \\epsilon_q . \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] in general for quantum operations @xmath16 . barring exceptional symmetric cases , @xmath17 if , and only if , all the output signal states @xmath18 share a common diagonalised basis , and there exists a common left stochastic map from diagonal elements of the input states ( in the diagonal basis of @xmath19 ) to eigenvalues of the output states .",
    "if these conditions do not hold , there is an excess , thermodynamically irreversible cost to any physical process that performs the quantum operation .",
    "this paper will define quantum operations , characterise the thermodynamics of implementing quantum operations , state the theorem , and then give examples of operations which meet , and operations which do not meet , the conditions for @xmath20 .",
    "while classical information processing is built up from logical operations such as and , or and not gates , the fundamental element in quantum information processing is the quantum operation @xcite .",
    "this acts upon one of a number of possible input states , each represented by a different quantum density matrix , @xmath21 , and maps each one to a specific output state @xmath22 .",
    "not all maps of the form @xmath22 are physically possible .",
    "a quantum operation , @xmath8 , must be a completely positive , trace preserving linear map : @xmath23 , with @xmath24 .",
    "when it is not a pure unitary rotation , a quantum operation requires the use of an auxiliary system @xmath25 , initially in a standard state , @xmath26 . a joint unitary @xmath27 acting on @xmath28 results in an entangled state of system and auxiliary",
    "( see figure [ f0 ] ) .",
    "the reduced state of the system , @xmath29 $ ] , is the output state ( see @xcite chapter 8 , for a textbook presentation ) .     to convert an input system state @xmath30 into an output state @xmath31 .",
    "an auxiliary input @xmath26 typically becomes entangled with the system and is discarded at the end of the operation . in order to understand the energy cost of the operation we should reset the auxiliary to its standard state @xmath26 in preparation for further uses",
    "this is done via interaction with a heat bath which starts in the canonical state @xmath32 .",
    "( ii ) an energetically suboptimal way to do this ignores any correlations between @xmath6 and @xmath25 and directly resets the auxiliary using the unitary @xmath33 which acts on the joint auxiliary - heat bath state . the output auxiliary state @xmath34 $ ] should be such that @xmath35 where @xmath2 is the probability of input @xmath3 ; the auxiliary is reset on average .",
    "( iii ) the optimal method typically can not be decomposed in this way and requires a unitary @xmath36 defined to act on system , auxiliary , and heat bath .",
    "@xmath36 should result in the same output state @xmath31 and reset the auxiliary : the output auxiliary state @xmath37 should be such that @xmath38 . for given average input @xmath19 and output @xmath39 , the average energy change which occurs in the heat bath",
    "will be lower bounded .",
    ", scaledwidth=30.0% ]",
    "it is essential , when quantifying the thermodynamic costs of operations , to keep track of the effects upon auxiliary systems .",
    "if an auxiliary is disregarded , then the quantum operation would appear to be performed without generating heat .",
    "however , this leaves the auxiliary in a state @xmath40 $ ] . simply discarding the auxiliary",
    "would , on average , change the entropy of the environment by @xmath41 $ ] where @xmath42=\\sum_n p_n { \\rho_{\\rm a}^{n\\prime}}$ ] .",
    "the most straightforward way to deal with this is to reset the auxiliary to its original state @xmath26 . to do this a thermal environment",
    "is introduced in the form of a heat bath in a canonical state @xmath32 at temperature @xmath43 .",
    "the reset can be performed by some unitary @xmath33 acting on both the auxiliary and the heat bath such that @xmath44 $ ] ( see figure [ f0 ] ) .",
    "this operation would transfer at least @xmath45 $ ] of heat to the heat bath @xcite .",
    "either way , the cost to the environment will generally be more than required by equation  ( [ bound ] ) .",
    "a quantum operation typically leaves correlations between system and auxiliary , with a mutual information @xcite of @xmath46 + \\left[s(\\rho_{\\rm a } ' ) - s(\\rho_{\\rm a})\\right ] \\geq 0 $ ] . simply resetting ( or discarding )",
    "the auxiliary will pay @xmath47 as an excess cost unless there is no correlation : @xmath48 .    to find the minimum thermodynamic cost of the quantum operation , the auxiliary must be reset more efficiently , exploiting correlations with the system .",
    "the unitary @xmath27 must be embedded in a larger unitary @xmath36 which includes interactions between system , auxiliary , and heat bath .",
    "@xmath36 must preserve the output of the computation @xmath49 & = { \\rho^{n\\prime}_{\\rm s } } ; \\label{ereset0}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] while resetting the auxiliary @xmath50 & = \\rho_{\\rm a } \\label{ereset}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] ( see figure [ f0 ] ) .",
    "standard calculations show that this implies equation ( [ bound ] ) ( see appendix [ sqtd ] ) .",
    "if the quantum operation is only defined for a single signal state , then physical implementations are possible which can get arbitrarily close to the equality in ( [ bound ] ) ( appendix [ arev ] ) .",
    "in general , a quantum operation must produce the result @xmath51 , for multiple signal states @xmath52 .",
    "the same @xmath36 must satisfy ( [ ereset0 ] ) for all @xmath3 .",
    "our principal result is to show this additional constraint forces a higher thermodynamic cost than equation  ( [ bound ] ) .",
    "an operation which generates a quantity of heat , @xmath53 , in excess of this bound will be thermodynamically irreversible , as any second operation which restores the original average state @xmath54 must necessarily leave a net heat gain in the heat bath of at least @xmath53 over the complete cycle .",
    "quantum computations can not , in general , be performed in a thermodynamically reversible manner .",
    "let @xmath55 $ ] be a quantum operation @xmath8 where @xmath32 is the state of a canonical heat bath at temperature @xmath43 , and @xmath26 is a standard state of an auxiliary which should be restored by the operation [ see equation  ( [ ereset ] ) ] .",
    "the average system input state @xmath19 can be expressed in terms of its diagonal basis vectors @xmath56 as @xmath57 similarly the average system output state can be expressed in terms of its diagonal basis vectors @xmath58 as @xmath59 in terms of these basis vectors the individual inputs and outputs are represented by @xmath60 we now state the theorem :    [ th1 ] if there exists a stochastic map , @xmath61 with @xmath62 such that @xmath63 for all @xmath3 , then the minimum thermodynamic cost of the operation @xmath64+\\epsilon_q , \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] can approach @xmath20 . otherwise , provided there are no symmetries of the form @xmath65 where @xmath66 or @xmath67 , then necessarily @xmath68 .    note that the set of properties @xmath69 , used to state the theorem",
    "are defined solely in terms of the quantum operation , independently of the particular physical process used to implement it .      in appendix [ nafs ]",
    "we show that the implementation of the operation can be re - written in the form @xmath70 where the complex coefficients @xmath71 carry the effects of interaction with the environment .",
    "they have the properties @xmath72 , and @xmath73 . in appendix [ sqtd ]",
    "we show that for a given physical implementation of the quantum operation where @xmath74 , and @xmath75 , @xmath76 finally in appendix [ sur ] we show that @xmath77 for which @xmath78 , then the implementation has an excess thermodynamic cost .",
    "the coefficients @xmath79 imply no bound as @xmath80 automatically holds for them . if equation  ( [ revcon ] ) holds , then @xmath81 gives an implementation with no excess cost ( see appendix [ proto ] for an explicit construction ) .",
    "otherwise , there must be some @xmath82 for @xmath83 or @xmath84 . if @xmath78 for any of these @xmath85 values , then there is an excess cost for that implementation .",
    "we can therefore use numerical optimisation techniques to find the coefficients satisfying ( [ mapp ] ) which minimise the largest value of ( [ eqbound1 ] ) , and equation  ( [ newbound ] ) shows this gives a lower bound for @xmath53 .",
    "when the output states do not have a shared diagonalised basis , so that there is some @xmath86 for @xmath84 , there is also an analytical bound : @xmath87 for further details see appendix [ secproof ] .",
    "this energy bound and others derived here may not be tight .",
    "it is an open problem to demonstrate a protocol which reaches @xmath53 - our results only place a non - zero lower bound on the excess energy cost .",
    "there are well known cases of quantum operations where @xmath20 .",
    "we now show how they fit into our proof .    _ pure unitary . _ in a pure unitary quantum operation , @xmath88 .",
    "this does not involve an auxiliary or heat bath , and does not change the eigenvalues of any input signal states .",
    "solutions with @xmath89 satisfy the operation , and the exceptional symmetry condition applies : the only terms which contribute to equation  ( [ mapp ] ) are ones for which @xmath65 .    _ single input .",
    "_ when there is only one possible input @xmath90 . as @xmath91 and @xmath92 , choosing @xmath93 shows that equation  ( [ revcon ] ) holds",
    "_ single output .",
    "_ resetting to a standard state is known to satisfy @xmath20 @xcite . in this case the output states for all inputs are of the form @xmath94 , so @xmath92 . again",
    ", choosing @xmath95 , shows that equation  ( [ revcon ] ) holds .",
    "_ classical information processing . _ for classical information processing , where the signal states correspond to orthogonal quantum states , @xmath20 @xcite .",
    "@xmath96 , so @xmath97 . in general the outputs",
    "take the form @xmath98 , representing a distribution of possible outputs @xmath99 , so @xmath100 , and equation  ( [ revcon ] ) holds .",
    "in general it will not be the case that @xmath20 .",
    "even the simplest quantum operations will fail to satisfy equation  ( [ revcon ] ) . as an example , we consider single qubit dephasing operations , which exhibit all the features of the theorem . inputs of the form @xmath101 with @xmath102 give outputs @xmath103 $ ] .",
    "each value of @xmath104 defines a different quantum operation , @xmath105 , with @xmath106 the identity , and @xmath107 completely dephasing the qubit .",
    "the operation @xmath108 can be implemented straightforwardly by a quantum cnot gate and an auxiliary , making our theorem open to experimental investigation @xcite . with the auxiliary initially prepared in the state @xmath109 acting as the target , we have @xmath110 .    _ non - diagonalisable outputs .",
    "_ when @xmath111 , the outputs , @xmath112 , will not typically be simultaneously diagonalisable .",
    "consider @xmath113 with two possible inputs : @xmath114 occurring with probability @xmath115 , and @xmath116 occurring with probability @xmath117 .",
    "after tracing away the auxiliary we find that the individual outputs are not simultaneously diagonalisable .",
    "there is enough information to calculate the lower bound on @xmath53 from equation  ( [ eqoffdiagm ] ) and this is found to be @xmath118 .",
    "this can be compared with the bound @xmath119 = -0.15 \\times kt$ ] .",
    "an overall negative value of @xmath120 indicates that this operation may still be used to extract energy from the heat bath .",
    "_ diagonalisable outputs .",
    "_ for @xmath107 , the outputs will be simultaneously diagonalised in the basis @xmath121 .",
    "we choose two pure state inputs : @xmath122 with probability @xmath123 , and @xmath124 with probability @xmath125 .",
    "the average input density matrix is therefore @xmath126 .",
    "figure [ f1 ] shows the minimum energy change in the heat bath with @xmath123 for four different pairs of inputs .",
    "we see that for some combinations of inputs there are no values of @xmath123 for which the operation can be thermodynamically reversible , and it necessarily requires an excess energy cost . for other inputs",
    "there are regions of @xmath123 where there is no excess cost and regions where there is a minimum non zero excess cost .",
    "figure [ f2 ] shows , for a given @xmath122 , the regions of @xmath124 on the bloch sphere where a zero excess cost is possible for various values of @xmath123 .",
    "further details of how to determine the minimum energy change in the heat bath can be found in appendix [ adp ] .",
    "the qubit dephasing example shows , in particular , that @xmath127 is possible both with @xmath128 and with non - trivial non - orthogonal input states , and that @xmath129 is possible even when the output states share a common diagonalisation .",
    "the excess thermodynamic costs of quantum operations stem from the requirement that the operation should get the computation right for every individual input , and not just on average . for",
    "well known cases , including classical information processing , we have shown how thermodynamic reversibility can be reached as a special case . however , for general quantum operations , with non - orthogonal signal states , an excess thermodynamic cost must be paid .",
    "this might seem counter intuitive , since quantum computations can always be represented as unitary operations , which can always be run in reverse . how can thermodynamic irreversibility arise with a reversible unitary operation ? simply running the overall unitary operation in reverse does not just tidy up the auxiliary , returning it to its initial state , but it also undoes the computation , converting the output back to the input . if we wish to retain the result of the computation , we can not simply reverse the unitary operation . in the classical reversible computing model of bennett @xcite , we save a copy of the output before reversing the computation . for quantum operations",
    "this is forbidden by the no - cloning theorem , and no quantum generalisation of bennett s procedure is possible @xcite .",
    "as long as we keep the results of the computation , we are left with the changes in the auxiliaries , representing spent resources and a cost to reset them to their initial states .",
    "this is the stage at which thermodynamic costs are incurred .",
    "we have shown that in general , for quantum operations this cost is necessarily in excess of the landauer limit given in equation  ( [ bound ] ) .",
    "quantum computing requires a thermodynamically irreversible generation of heat .",
    "we would like to thank chris timpson and oscar dahlsten for discussions .",
    "this work was funded by the templeton world charity foundation .",
    "given an input @xmath7 and an output @xmath130 of a quantum operation @xmath8 on a quantum system @xmath6 we can describe the operation as @xmath131 , \\label{qop}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the subscript on the trace indicates which components have been traced over . the unitary @xmath36 acts on an initial state @xmath132 which includes ,",
    "besides the system , a thermal environment in the form of a canonical heat bath , @xmath32 , and an auxiliary to be used as a catalyst @xmath26 . given that inputs @xmath7 appear with probability @xmath2 we can define an average system input state and an average system output state by @xmath133 respectively .    the auxiliary is a resource which is spent by the operation .",
    "in order to account for this cost we demand that it must be returned to the same standard state @xmath26 at the end of the computation @xmath134 = \\rho_{\\rm a}. \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] this ensures that the auxiliary can be reused in subsequent computations .",
    "we need only demand that the auxiliary is reset on average .    for convenience",
    "we define the following notation @xmath135 . \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    we can choose to work in a basis in which @xmath19 is diagonal . in general @xmath39 will not be diagonal in this basis but we can perform a final rotation to make it so : @xmath136 , \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] or @xmath137 .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] now drop the bars from the notation and assume without loss of generality that the average system inputs and outputs are diagonalised in the same basis .",
    "let us denote these diagonal basis states by @xmath56 .",

    "[ l0 ] the energy change in the heat bath as a result of a quantum operation @xmath8 on a system @xmath6 implemented by some unitary @xmath157 , involving a resetting of the auxiliary system @xmath25 , is given by @xmath158 + s(\\rho'||\\rho_{\\star } ) .",
    "\\label{eresult0}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath159 .",
    "the schumacher information measure is given by @xmath160 $ ] and we use a definition of the relative entropy using log base 2 @xmath161-{{\\rm tr}}\\left[\\rho\\log_2\\sigma\\right ] .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the energy change in the bath is given by @xmath162 $ ] where @xmath163 is the heat bath hamiltonian .",
    "a standard result is that @xcite @xmath164 it follows that @xmath165   + s(\\rho'_{\\rm b}||\\rho_{\\rm b } ) \\nonumber \\\\ = & s(\\rho'_{\\rm b } ) - \\left[s(\\rho ' ) - s(\\rho_{\\rm s } ) - s(\\rho_{\\rm a})\\right ]   + s(\\rho'_{\\rm b}||\\rho_{\\rm b } ) \\nonumber \\\\ = & \\left [ s(\\rho_{{\\rm s } } ) - s(\\rho'_{{\\rm s}})\\right ] + s(\\rho'_{\\rm b}||\\rho_{\\rm b})\\nonumber\\\\ & \\quad+\\left [ s(\\rho'_{{\\rm s } } ) + s(\\rho_{\\rm a } ) + s(\\rho'_{\\rm b } ) - s(\\rho ' ) \\right ] .",
    "\\label{decalc}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] since the last term in square brackets in the last line must be positive by subadditivity and the relative entropy term must be positive as a result of klein s inequality , we must have @xmath166 . \\label{land}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the operation satisfies thermodynamic reversibility if the inequality is saturated .",
    "this can be seen by forming a second operation @xmath167 which restores the original average state .",
    "there must be a net heat gain in the heat bath if , for any part of the cycle , the equality in ( [ land ] ) does not hold .",
    "write @xmath168 . as a result of the fact that @xmath169 factorises we find that @xmath170 - { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho ' \\left ( \\log_2\\rho'_{\\rm s}\\otimes { \\mathbb 1}_{\\rm a}\\otimes{\\mathbb 1}_{\\rm b}\\right ) ] \\nonumber\\\\ & - { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho ' \\left ( { \\mathbb 1}_{\\rm s}\\otimes \\log_2\\rho_{\\rm a } \\otimes{\\mathbb 1}_{\\rm b}\\right ) ] \\nonumber\\\\ & -   { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho'\\left({\\mathbb 1}_{\\rm s}\\otimes{\\mathbb 1}_{\\rm",
    "a}\\otimes\\log_2\\rho_{\\rm b}\\right)]\\nonumber\\\\ = & { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho'\\log_2\\rho ' ] - { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho'_{\\rm s}\\log_2\\rho'_{\\rm s } ] \\nonumber\\\\ & - { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho_{\\rm a}\\log_2\\rho_{\\rm a } ] - { { \\rm tr}}[\\rho'_{\\rm b}\\log_2\\rho_{\\rm b } ] \\nonumber\\\\ = & s(\\rho_{\\rm b}'||\\rho_{\\rm b})\\nonumber\\\\ & + \\left[s(\\rho_{\\rm s } ' ) + s(\\rho_{\\rm a } ) + s(\\rho_{\\rm b } ' ) - s(\\rho ' ) \\right ] , \\label{recalc}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] so that from ( [ decalc ] ) @xmath171 + s(\\rho'||\\rho_{\\star } ) .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the quantity @xmath172 therefore encodes the extent to which the thermodynamic bound on the energy change ( [ land ] ) is breached .",
    "the demand for @xmath173 requires from ( [ recalc ] ) that both @xmath174 and @xmath175 .",
    "in particular the second of these conditions suggests an output state with @xmath176 and therefore no energy change in the heat bath .",
    "in fact , in the limit where the dimension of the heat bath becomes large , it is possible to have @xmath177 sufficiently close to @xmath32 such that @xmath178 for some arbitrarily small @xmath179 whilst at the same time @xmath180 for some fixed non zero @xmath181 . to see this",
    "we write @xmath182 where @xmath183 is a fixed traceless matrix and @xmath184 is a small parameter .",
    "the change in energy of the heat bath is given by @xmath185 = \\varepsilon { { \\rm tr } } [ h_{\\rm b } \\delta ] .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] now suppose that we have @xmath186 identical independent copies of the same heat bath ( this will also be a canonical state ) .",
    "if we further suppose that each copy undergoes the same uncorrelated change @xmath182 , then to lowest order , the energy change of the @xmath186-copy heat bath is @xmath187 this means that we can take @xmath188 and as @xmath186 becomes large , @xmath189 remains fixed .",
    "now consider the relative entropy between @xmath32 and @xmath177 @xmath190 + { \\cal",
    "o}(\\varepsilon^2 ) \\nonumber\\\\ & =   { \\cal o}(\\varepsilon^2 ) . \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the correction to the relative entropy is at least quadratic in @xmath184 .",
    "the relative entropy for the @xmath186-copy heat bath is @xmath191 therefore , in the limit that @xmath186 becomes large and @xmath188 tends to zero , the relative entropy for the @xmath186-copy heat bath tends to zero .",
    "this simple example demonstrates that it is legitimate for the relative entropy to tend to zero whilst the energy change in the heat bath remains non zero .",
    "[ c0 ] the energy change in the heat bath is bounded by @xmath192 + \\frac{1}{2}kt|| \\rho'-\\rho_{\\star}||_1 ^ 2 .",
    "\\label{eresult}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    we use @xcite @xmath193 the result follows from equation  ( [ eresult0 ] ) .",
    "there is a standard protocol for reaching the bound given in equation  ( [ land ] ) , appearing in various forms in the literature ( @xcite for examples ) , when the quantum operation is defined only to act upon an individual density matrix @xmath194 of a system @xmath6 ( see also @xcite for alternative protocols to reach the bound ) .",
    "note that these protocols do not require that either the initial or final states are in thermal equilibrium .",
    "the density matrix is initially in the state @xmath195 where @xmath196 are orthonormal eigenstates .",
    "the result of the operation @xmath8 is a state @xmath197 for a possibly different set of orthonormal eigenstates @xmath198 .",
    "we assume that both the initial and final sets of eigenstates are fully degenerate in energy with energy level zero .",
    "this avoids the complication of the system being used as a source or sink of energy .",
    "_ step 1_. starting with @xmath19 , manipulate the energy levels @xmath199 of each eigenstate @xmath200 until @xmath201 where @xmath202 .",
    "this has a mean cost @xmath203 .",
    "the new density matrix will now be canonically distributed at temperature @xmath43 .",
    "_ step 2_. bring the system into contact with a heat bath at temperature @xmath43 .",
    "_ step 3_. slowly , isothermally , change the energy eigenstates until they satisfy @xmath204 the energy requirement for this is @xmath205 .",
    "the density matrix is now canonically distributed at temperature @xmath43 , with eigenvalues @xmath206 .",
    "_ step 4_. remove the system from contact with the heat bath .",
    "_ step 5_. change the energy levels of the eigenstates back to zero , with a mean cost @xmath207 .",
    "_ step 6_. perform a unitary rotation to the final eigenstates @xmath208 .",
    "the operation is complete with a cost of @xmath209 .",
    "\\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] it is worth noting that this protocol works even when the system is a joint system with non - trivial correlations or entanglement between subsystems @xcite .    during the stages in which we manipulate the energy levels of the system",
    "we are assuming a time - dependent hamiltonian @xmath210 for the system and a standard definition of the mean rate of work given by @xmath211 $ ] .",
    "this presupposes some idealised work reservoir , capable of doing work on ( or taking work from ) the system by manipulation of the hamiltonian .",
    "we will denote this operation @xmath212 .",
    "as shown in @xcite , the theoretical energy cost can only be acheived in an aymptotic limit .",
    "nevertheless , there is no physical principle which prevents us from getting arbitrarily close this value .",
    "the following relation holds @xmath213 - \\lambda'_l { { \\rm tr}}[a_{mi}a_{lj}^{\\dagger}\\delta_{km } ] \\right ) .",

    "the coefficients @xmath71 are given in ( [ qcoef ] ) .",

    "\\label{el3}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] let us define some arbitrary basis states @xmath220 for the complete system , auxiliary , and heat bath .",
    "we can write @xmath221 then @xmath222\\right| & = \\left|\\sum_{xy } g^l_{xy}r_{yx}\\right|   \\nonumber\\\\ & \\leq \\sum_x \\left|\\sum_y g^l_{xy}r_{yx}\\right| \\nonumber\\\\ & \\leq \\sum_x \\left(\\sum_y |g^l_{xy}|^2\\right)^{\\frac{1}{2}}\\left(\\sum_z |r_{zx}|^2\\right)^{\\frac{1}{2 } } , \\label{g1eq}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the second line follows from the triangle inequality and the third line follows from the cauchy - schwartz inequality . similarly @xmath223\\right| \\leq",
    "\\sum_x \\left(\\sum_y |g^r_{yx}|^2\\right)^{\\frac{1}{2}}\\left(\\sum_z |r_{xz}|^2\\right)^{\\frac{1}{2}}. \\label{g2eq}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] next we show that @xmath224 and @xmath225 the operator products can be written as @xmath226 we also have @xmath227 which follows from ( [ g4 ] ) and ( [ g5 ] ) .",
    "since the identity is expressed as a sum of positive operators and since @xmath228 is a sum of a subset of these positive operators , it must be the case that the diagonal elements of @xmath228 in the arbitrary basis @xmath220 must belong to the range @xmath229 $ ] from which ( [ rdiag ] ) follows .",
    "similarly for ( [ ldiag ] ) .",

    ".    if equation  ( [ revconsi ] ) does not hold , then some values of @xmath71 with @xmath66 or @xmath67 must be non - zero , in any implementation .",
    "for a given implementation , the largest value of the lower bound of equation  ( [ lem2eq ] ) across all @xmath85 determines an excess thermodynamic cost .",
    "if there are no symmetries of the form @xmath65 with @xmath66 or @xmath67 , then this lower bound must be greater than zero .",

    "as the right hand side only involves terms independent of the specific implementation , then this bound must hold for all implementations and so by corollary [ c0 ] , @xmath268 if all @xmath269 , with @xmath84 , but equation  ( [ revconsi ] ) does not hold , then @xmath270 and any implementation must have values of @xmath271 with @xmath83 . we can find complex coefficients @xmath272 , which satisfy equation  ( [ eqdiag ] ) , while minimising the largest value of the lower bound of ( [ lem2eq ] ) , @xmath273 .",
    "this must be done using numerical optimisation techniques on a case - by - case basis .",
    "given the set @xmath274 , this establishes a minimum value for @xmath275 and therefore , by corollary [ c0 ] , a minimum excess cost across all possible implementations , so again @xmath68 .",
    "we now demonstrate a protocol which can achieve @xmath20 for the special class of quantum operations which satisfy equation  ( [ revconsi ] ) . for these operations there",
    "exists a stochastic map @xmath61 such that the input and output states of a quantum operation are related by @xmath276 .",
    "let the initial state of the auxiliary be @xmath277 , so the combined system and auxiliary is initially @xmath278    _ step 1_. use the auxiliary to measure the input system in the basis of the average input density matrix .",
    "correlate the auxiliary to the system using a unitary with @xmath279 .",
    "the joint state is now @xmath280    _ step 2_. the operation @xmath281 ( see appendix [ proto ] ) performs a thermodynamically optimal conversion of @xmath282 to @xmath283 .",
    "the conditional operation @xmath284 puts the joint system in the state @xmath285 transferring mean heat to the heat bath @xmath286 .",
    "the average state takes the form @xmath287    _ step 3_. we now exploit the correlations between system and auxiliary to optimally reset the auxiliary .",
    "the operation @xmath288 performs an optimal conversion of @xmath289 to @xmath277 , where @xmath290 is the mean conditional probability of the auxiliary state being @xmath291 given that the system state is @xmath292 . the conditional operation @xmath293 resets the auxiliary to @xmath277 while transferring mean heat @xmath294 .",
    "the joint state is now @xmath295 and provided the conditions of the theorem hold , the system is in the correct output state , up to a unitary .",
    "the average heat production is readily confirmed to be @xmath296 $ ] thus proving that @xmath297 .",
    "it is important to note that , if the conditions of the theorem do not apply , this protocol not only fails to be optimal , but fails to correctly implement the operation at all , i.e. @xmath298 is not mapped to the correct @xmath31 .",
    "we analyse the specific example of a qubit dephasing operation .",
    "this can be implemented using a cnot . for this operation",
    "an input of the form @xmath101 with @xmath299 gives the output @xmath300 .",
    "all outputs are simultaneously diagonalisable in the @xmath301 basis .",
    "we choose two pure state inputs @xmath122 and @xmath124 such that the average input state is @xmath302 for some probability @xmath123 .",
    "all of the elements @xmath303 are specified by the operation together with the form and relative frequency of the inputs . to find @xmath304 we determine the diagonal basis of @xmath19 and express the individual inputs in this basis @xmath305 the output elements are @xmath306 the elements must satisfy equation  ( [ eqrewrite1 ] ) for some set of coefficients @xmath71 .",
    "the off - diagonal elements of the outputs can be solved by choosing @xmath307 for @xmath67 , implying no constraint on excess heat cost by lemma [ lem3 ] . for the diagonal elements of the outputs we denote @xmath308 , and @xmath309 , @xmath310 , so that from equation  ( [ eqrewrite1 ] ) we can write @xmath311 and @xmath312 since @xmath313 , @xmath314 , and @xmath315 , these pairs of equations are equivalent",
    ", so we focus on the first pair .",
    "the remaining numerical problem is to find the @xmath316 with the smallest magnitude which can solve this pair of equations with @xmath317 .",
    "this is done by scanning complex values of @xmath316 of increasing magnitude and solving for @xmath318 and @xmath319 until they both fit within the required range .",
    "once we have found @xmath320 we can use lemma [ lem2 ] to bound @xmath321 : @xmath264 where @xmath322 are the eigenvalues of @xmath19 .",
    "finally we can use equation  ( [ eresult ] ) to bound the energy cost : @xmath323 + \\frac{1}{2 } kt ( \\lambda_1-\\lambda_2)^2 |w|^2_{min}. \\nonumber\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] examples are given in figure [ f1 ] .",

    "t.  sagawa , in _ lectures on quantum computing , thermodynamics and statistical physics _ , m. nakahara and s. tanaka ( eds . ) , kinki university series on quantum computing ( world scientific , 2012 ) . j.  goold & k.  modi , phys .",
    "e*90 * , 020101(r ) ( 2014 ) .",
    "j.  goold , m.  paternostro , & k.  modi , phys .",
    "lett .  * 114 * , 060602 ( 2015 ) .",
    "b.  w.  schumacher .",
    "rev .  a  * 51 * ( 4 ) 27382747 ( 1995 ) .",
    "m.  h.  partovi , phys .",
    "lett .  a  * 137 * 440 ( 1989 )",
    ". o.  j.  e. maroney , _ the physical basis of the gibbs - von neumann entropy .",
    "_ , arxiv : quant - ph/0701127 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> the amount of heat generated by computers is rapidly becoming one of the main problems for developing new generations of information technology . </S>",
    "<S> the thermodynamics of computation sets the ultimate physical bounds on heat generation . </S>",
    "<S> a lower bound is set by the landauer limit , at which computation becomes thermodynamically reversible . for classical computation </S>",
    "<S> there is no physical principle which prevents this limit being reached , and approaches to it are already being experimentally tested . in this paper </S>",
    "<S> we show that for quantum computation there is an unavoidable excess heat generation that renders it inherently thermodynamically irreversible . </S>",
    "<S> the landauer limit can not , in general , be reached by quantum computers . </S>",
    "<S> we show the existence of a lower bound to the heat generated by quantum computing that exceeds that given by the landauer limit , give the special conditions where this excess cost may be avoided , and show how classical computing falls within these special conditions . </S>"
  ]
}
